ooohh, yagu, that's teasing :-). Tell us more......

Thanks Jim, I guess the Mimi was what threw me, though my Tadatoki 
mokume tsuba's mimi is as square as my last assistant, and that's 
square. I think the sharpness of the sukashi is Akasaka-ish, as is the 
design as a whole. I thought Akao because of it's overall boldness and 
the fact that they were copying Akasaka along with Tosa Myochin and visa 
versa at the later stages of the Edo period.

Though, from the photo's, I would think this a bit older than late Edo ?.

Cheers

Rich

Jim Gilbert wrote:

> Curran,
> Number 482 was a Myochin tsuba with a circular cross section rim and a 
> design of two large diamond shapes at 12:00 and 6:00.  That's the only 
> thing similar in your group.  I know the owner, so I'm guessing it's 
> the one you're thinking of.
>
> I've seen the spiral motif used on a guard signed Tadatoki, and as 
> Rich said the insect is often seen in Akasaka sukashi.  I don't think 
> Akasaka is a bad call.
>
> Rich, what's putting you off Akasaka?
>
> Back to the Yagyu,
> Jim
>

--
